newsitem.title: USA: April snow knocks out power across U.S. Northeast.
newsitem.headline: April snow knocks out power across U.S. Northeast.

text.p: Utilities in the Northeast and New England were reporting more than 250,000 customers without power as wet, heavy snow and high winds pelted the region.
Utility company spokesmen said some of their customers would remain without electricity through Friday.

Northeast Utilities, which serves Connecticut and western Massachusetts, reported 100,000 customers without power. Eastern Utilities, which serves Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts, reported 31,000 customers without service.

"We expect to have most service back this evening, but in the Brockton (Mass.) area, customers may not get service back before Thursday," Eastern Utilities spokeswoman Elaine Hunt said. At the height of the storm, some 51,000 Eastern Utilities customers were powerless.
Boston Edison reported more than 50,000 customers without power.

"We've had a 100 crews on all night and we know 36 crews are headed here from Canada. We're also looking for help from New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Vermont," Boston Edison spokesman Mike Monahan said.
He estimated it would be up to a week before service was fully restored to all 50,000 customers.

Public Service Co of New Hampshire (PSNH) was reporting 6,100 customers without service with significant outages in Manchester, Hillsboro and Newport. A spokeswoman said the company was able to bring in crews from Canada to help with the battle of downed powerlines.
Central Maine Power reported 1,800 customers were without power on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, in New York, Long Island Lighting Co (LILCO) said 3,400 of 31,000 customers, whose service was disrupted overnight, were still without power early Tuesday.

Most of the outages was caused by high winds and wet snow snapping overhead power lines, but in a few cases, the wires were knocked down due to cars skidding into roadside power poles, a LILCO spokeswoman said.
"There were no transmission outages," she added.
Consolidated Edison Co of New York (Con Ed) said a total of 16,000 of its customers, mostly in suburban Westchester County just north of New York City, lost power during the snowy, windy night.
"We're looking at a majority of them restored tonight," said Con Ed spokesman Michael Spall, referring to the 13,000 customers still without power this morning.
In northern New Jersey, Public Service Electric and Gas Co (PSE&G) said about 5,000 electricity customers were still without power. At the height of the storm, 30,000 customers were in the dark.
The hardest hit area was Princeton, where 2,500 customers were still without service due primarily to circuit problems.
The spokesman could not comment on when full restoration of service would occur.
The utility, a unit of Public Service Enterprise Inc, serves 2.2 million electric and gas customers throughout the state.
